squidpony.squidmath

Class ZapRNG

  • java.lang.Object
    • squidpony.squidmath.ZapRNG
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, RandomnessSource

    @Beta
public class ZapRNG
extends Object
implements RandomnessSource, Serializable
    A variant on LapRNG that improves the quality at the expense of some speed. Running ZapRNG through PractRand, a tool for evaluating the statistical quality of PRNGs, found far, far fewer statistical failures than LapRNG, and also had them generally be less severe. The period is still relatively low, at (with a high degree of certainty) 2 to the 65, but the speed is still fairly good; slightly faster than ThunderRNG (an earlier version was within 1% difference, but subsequent changes sped up Zap by about 5-10%), faster than LightRNG all around, slower than LapRNG for all methods, and slower than FlapRNG on next() and nextInt() but not on nextLong(). Like LapRNG, there should be many possible sequences of length (2 to the 65) this can produce, depending on the relationship between the two longs used for state, determined at construction or when the seed is set.
    Created by Tommy Ettinger on 6/7/2017.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ZapRNG()
      Constructs a ZapRNG with a random internal state, using Math.random() three times to get enough bits.
      ZapRNG(CharSequence seed)
      This constructor gets three differently-calculated 32-bit hash codes from the given String or other CharSequence and gives them to the constructor that takes three ints, ZapRNG(int, int, int).
      ZapRNG(int seed)
      Given one int for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant.
      ZapRNG(int seed0, int seed1)
      This constructor takes ints for seeds, but internally ZapRNG uses longs, so it multiplies each input by a large constant and adds another to get the state it actually will start with.
      ZapRNG(int seed0, int seed1, int seed2)
      This constructor takes 3 ints for seeds, but internally ZapRNG uses 2 longs (one, state0, only considers its upper 48 bits significant and has closely correlated results if inputs don't differ on significant bits).
      ZapRNG(long seed)
      Given one long for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant.
      ZapRNG(long seed0, long seed1)
      The only constructor that does not modify its seeds in some way; you should ensure seed0 is large enough (at least 25 bits should be needed to represent it, so greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433).

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(long seed)
        Given one long for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
        Parameters:
        seed - any long; will not be used verbatim for either internal state

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(int seed)
        Given one int for a seed, this fills the two internal longs of state with different values, each produced by multiplying seed by a large constant and adding a different large constant. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
        Parameters:
        seed - any int; will not be used verbatim for either internal state

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(long seed0,
              long seed1)
        The only constructor that does not modify its seeds in some way; you should ensure seed0 is large enough (at least 25 bits should be needed to represent it, so greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433). If seed0 is too small, then this will appear highly repetitive for many cycles before changing its output pattern.
        Parameters:
        seed0 - a long that should be greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433, preferably by a large amount
        seed1 - any long

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(int seed0,
              int seed1)
        This constructor takes ints for seeds, but internally ZapRNG uses longs, so it multiplies each input by a large constant and adds another to get the state it actually will start with. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
        Parameters:
        seed0 - any int, will not be used verbatim
        seed1 - any int, will not be used verbatim

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(int seed0,
              int seed1,
              int seed2)
        This constructor takes 3 ints for seeds, but internally ZapRNG uses 2 longs (one, state0, only considers its upper 48 bits significant and has closely correlated results if inputs don't differ on significant bits). To ensure the state works fairly well, this uses seed0 to affect the upper 48 bits of state0 (this also uses the product of seed1 and seed2), while employing all 3 seed parameters again to set state1 (but these can affect all 64 bits of state1). Note that only 96 bits of parameter are supplied here to set 128 bits of state, which is all right in this case because ZapRNG only has a period of 2 to the 65. Anything more than 65 bits of state isn't strictly necessary, though giving more should allow different, non-overlapping sequences to be produced. You can obtain the state that this ends up using with getState0() and getState1().
        Parameters:
        seed0 - any int, will not be used verbatim
        seed1 - any int, will not be used verbatim
        seed2 - any int, will not be used verbatim

      • ZapRNG

        public ZapRNG(CharSequence seed)
        This constructor gets three differently-calculated 32-bit hash codes from the given String or other CharSequence and gives them to the constructor that takes three ints, ZapRNG(int, int, int). You can pass a null seed and this will still work.
        Parameters:
        seed - any CharSequence, such as a String

    • Method Detail

      • next

        public final int next(int bits)
        Using this method, any algorithm that might use the built-in Java Random can interface with this randomness source.
        Specified by:
        next in interface RandomnessSource
        Parameters:
        bits - the number of bits to be returned
        Returns:
        the integer containing the appropriate number of bits

      • nextInt

        public final int nextInt()
        Gets a pseudo-random int, which can be positive or negative but is likely to be drawn from less possible options than the full range of Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE. Very fast, though.
        Returns:
        a pseudo-random 32-bit int

      • nextLong

        public final long nextLong()
        Using this method, any algorithm that needs to efficiently generate more than 32 bits of random data can interface with this randomness source. This implementation is the primary one, and nextInt() and next(int) just use some portion of the bits this produces. It should be fairly fast on desktops, with good-not-great quality, unlike alternatives such as LapRNG, which is extremely fast but has low quality when inspected enough, and LightRNG, which the fastest of the "Made by an Expert" RandomnessSources and has superior quality but is somewhat slower.

        Pseudo-random results may be between between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).

        Specified by:
        nextLong in interface RandomnessSource
        Returns:
        a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive)

      • copy

        public RandomnessSource copy()
        Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just need to copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
        Specified by:
        copy in interface RandomnessSource
        Returns:
        a copy of this RandomnessSource

      • getState0

        public long getState0()
        Gets the linearly-changing part of the state.
        Returns:
        one of the two parts of the state as a long

      • setState0

        public void setState0(long state0)
        Sets the linearly-changing part of the state; if the parameter is too small, the generator will behave poorly. At minimum, the parameter should have significant bits beyond the 24th bit (greater than 33554432 for positive longs), and should ideally be larger than can be represented in a 32-bit int.
        Parameters:
        state0 - a large-enough long, either greater than 33554432 or less than -33554433, preferably greatly so

      • getState1

        public long getState1()
        Gets the irregularly-changing part of the state.
        Returns:
        one of the two parts of the state as a long

      • setState1

        public void setState1(long state1)
        Sets the irregularly-changing part of the state; just about any long can be passed as a reasonable value here.
        Parameters:
        state1 - any long

      • determine

        public static long determine(long state)
        Gets a seemingly-random value from one inputs as a long. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique (state += ZapRNG.determine(state) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), which will update each call to use different values for state (it may be surprising that it is an expression that returns the value of state1 after assignment, so the parenthesized expression can be substituted for the method call on its own). You may want to experiment with using ^= or -= instead of += in the given code, which may affect the results quite a bit.
        Parameters:
        state - any long
        Returns:
        any long, from the full range

      • determine

        public static long determine(long state0,
                             long state1)
        Gets a seemingly-random value from two inputs as longs. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique (state1 ^= ZapRNG.determine((state0 += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), state1)), which will update each call to use different values for state0 and state1 (it may be surprising that it is an expression that returns the value of state1 after assignment, so the parenthesized expression can be substituted for the method call on its own). You may want to experiment with using += or -= instead of ^= in the given code, which will affect the results quite a bit. Unlike ZapRNG(long, long), this does not have any special requirements for state0, and both parameters should be free to be large or small.
        Parameters:
        state0 - any long
        state1 - any long
        Returns:
        any long, from the full range

      • determineBounded

        public static int determineBounded(long state,
                                   int bound)
        Gets a seemingly-random value between 0 and bound, given two state values as longs. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique ZapRNG.determineBounded((state0 += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), state1 += state0 >> 1), which will update each call to use different values for state0 and state1.
        Parameters:
        state - any long
        bound - the outer bound, exclusive
        Returns:
        any long, from the full range

      • determineBounded

        public static int determineBounded(long state0,
                                   long state1,
                                   int bound)
        Gets a seemingly-random value between 0 and bound, given two state values as longs. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique ZapRNG.determineBounded((state0 += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), state1 += state0 >> 1), which will update each call to use different values for state0 and state1.
        Parameters:
        state0 - any long
        state1 - any long
        bound - the outer bound, exclusive
        Returns:
        any long, from the full range

      • randomDouble

        public static double randomDouble(long state0,
                                  long state1)
        Gets a seemingly-random double from two inputs as longs. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique ZapRNG.randomDouble((state0 += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), (state1 += state0 >> 1)), which will update each call to use different values for state0 and state1, with state1 depending on state0. Unlike ZapRNG(long, long), this does not have any special requirements for state0, and both parameters should be free to be large or small.
        Parameters:
        state0 - any long
        state1 - any long
        Returns:
        a pseudo-random double from 0.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)

      • randomSignedDouble

        public static double randomSignedDouble(long state0,
                                        long state1)
        Gets a seemingly-random double between -1.0 and 1.0 from two inputs as longs. If you expect to call this method repeatedly, consider using the technique ZapRNG.randomSignedDouble((state0 += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L), (state1 += state0 >> 1)), which will update each call to use different values for state0 and state1, with state1 depending on state0. Unlike ZapRNG(long, long), this does not have any special requirements for state0, and both parameters should be free to be large or small.
        Parameters:
        state0 - any long
        state1 - any long
        Returns:
        a pseudo-random double from -1.0 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive)

      • randomFloat

Unlike ZapRNG(long, long), this does not have any special requirements for state0, and both parameters should be free to be large or small.
